caseTitle: ANSAH VERSUS BOYE AND WEST AND SOUTH AFRICAN MINES LTD.
summary: In Ansa v. Boye and West and South African Mines Ltd., the West African Court of Appeal considered whether an employer was vicariously liable for a driver's negligent collision occurring two hours after work ended and far from the designated route. The driver, instructed to garage his lorry after delivering manganese at 6 p.m., was involved in an accident at 8 p.m. while allegedly teaching someone to drive. The trial court found he was on a personal errand, thus absolving the employer. On appeal, the court emphasized that liability depends on whether the servant was acting within the scope of employment or on a 'frolic of his own.' While minor detours may not break the employment chain, a substantial deviation in time and route—especially for personal purposes—can. The court noted insufficient evidence to confirm the driver’s activities during the two-hour gap but highlighted that if he was merely taking a circuitous route, liability might still attach. However, embarking on a completely new journey for personal reasons would sever the employer's responsibility.
verdict: Appeal allowed in part; remitted for reconsideration of whether the deviation constituted a frolic of his own or remained within the course of employment.
winningSide: Plaintiff (partial win on legal principle, case remitted)

jurisdiction.court: West African Court of Appeal, Gold Coast Session

citations: Goh Choon Seng v. Lee Kim Soo [1925] A.C. 550
Canadian Pacific Railway Co. v. Lockhart [1942] A.C. 591
rationaleHighlights: Liability hinges on whether servant was acting within course of employment or on a 'frolic of his own'.
Unauthorized detours do not automatically absolve employer; key is whether deviation constitutes a new journey.
Time and route deviations are both relevant in determining employment status.
Master liable if servant performs authorized tasks in unauthorized manner, but not if engaged in wholly personal business.
Mitchell v. Crassweller distinguished: servant here may have still been partially on employer's business.
confidenceNotes: High confidence in key legal principles; some uncertainty regarding exact activities during 2-hour gap due to lack of evidence.
